title: How to Bake a Lady Baltimore Cake

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 180℃/350℉/Gas 4.
steps.description: Grease two 23cm/9in round cake tins (pans) and line with baking parchment. Grease the paper. In a bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder and salt. Set aside.

steps.headline: With an electric mixer, beat the eggs and sugar until thick and lemon-colored.
steps.description: Beat in the orange rind and juice, then the oil.

steps.headline: On low speed, beat in the flour mixture in three batches.
steps.description: Divide the cake mixture between the tins.

steps.headline: Bake until a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean, about 30 minutes.
steps.description: Leave to stand for 15 minutes, then run a knife around the inside of the cakes and transfer them to racks to cool completely.

steps.headline: Combine the egg whites, sugar, water and cream of tartar in the top of a double boiler, or in a heatproof bowl set over boiling water.
steps.description: With an electric mixer, beat until glossy and thick. Off the heat, add the vanilla extract and continue beating until thick. Fold in the pecan nuts, raisins and figs.

steps.headline: Spread a layer of icing on top of one cake.
steps.description: Sandwich with the second cake, then spread the top and sides with the rest of the icing. Arrange the pecan halves on top.

text: Cake Preheat the oven to 180℃/350℉/Gas 4. Grease two 23cm/9in round cake tins (pans) and line with baking parchment. Grease the paper. In a bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder and salt. Set aside. With an electric mixer, beat the eggs and sugar until thick and lemon-colored. Beat in the orange rind and juice, then the oil. On low speed, beat in the flour mixture in three batches. Divide the cake mixture between the tins. Bake until a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean, about 30 minutes. Leave to stand for 15 minutes, then run a knife around the inside of the cakes and transfer them to racks to cool completely. Filling and topping Combine the egg whites, sugar, water and cream of tartar in the top of a double boiler, or in a heatproof bowl set over boiling water. With an electric mixer, beat until glossy and thick. Off the heat, add the vanilla extract and continue beating until thick. Fold in the pecan nuts, raisins and figs. Spread a layer of icing on top of one cake. Sandwich with the second cake, then spread the top and sides with the rest of the icing. Arrange the pecan halves on top.
